page.title: 15Conservation in Shelsley
page.content: The temperature in the valley is usually recognised as being slightly higher than in the surrounding countryside. Average rainfall 400' above the valley was 2.29" measured over nine years. The Shelsleys is a clean area as far as{water pollution}is concerned. Supplies are monitored at Stanford Bridge and tests reveal virtually no organic or toxic metal pollution, nor any great problem from pesticides or herbicides. Recently increasing levels of nitrates now seem to be levelling off. Under the auspices of the{Worcs. {Trust for nature conservation}a reserve is maintained at{Penny Hill {Bank.}General conservation includes mechanical cutting of hedges, cutting verges of only one yard and reshaping river banks.
